elements.content: Helical coordination complexes, {[M(pyrimidine)(OH2)4][SiF6]·H2O}∞; (M = Co, 1; Cu, 2; Zn, 3), were inadvertently but reproducibly isolated when corresponding metal tetrafluoroborates were reacted with pyrimidine in glass vials in 1:1 molar ratios. The crystal structures of complexes 1−3 revealed spontaneously resolved helical coordination polymers in enantiomorphic space groups P43212 (1) and P41212 (2 and 3) despite the high molecular symmetry associated with the constituent building blocks. The individual helical polymer chains were linked together by hydrogen bonding involving the H2O solvent and SiF6 2- anions to form a topologically complex three-dimensional network.
elements.clean_text: Helical coordination complexes, {[M(pyrimidine)(OH2)4][SiF6]⋅H2O}∞; (M = Co, 1; Cu, 2; Zn, 3), were inadvertently but reproducibly isolated when corresponding metal tetrafluoroborates were reacted with pyrimidine in glass vials in 1:1 molar ratios. The crystal structures of complexes 1-3 revealed spontaneously resolved helical coordination polymers in enantiomorphic space groups P43212 (1) and P41212 (2 and 3) despite the high molecular symmetry associated with the constituent building blocks. The individual helical polymer chains were linked together by hydrogen bonding involving the H2O solvent and SiF6 2- anions to form a topologically complex three-dimensional network.

elements.content: Helical coordination polymers, {[M(pyrimidine)(OH2)4][SiF6]·H2O}∞; (M = Co, 1; Cu, 2; Zn, 3), were inadvertently isolated when corresponding metal tetrafluoroborates were reacted with pyrimidine in glass vials. The crystal structures of complexes 1−3 revealed spontaneously resolved P (1) and M (2 and 3) helical coordination polymers in enantiomorphic space groups, despite the high molecular symmetry associated with the constituent building blocks.
elements.clean_text: Helical coordination polymers, {[M(pyrimidine)(OH2)4][SiF6]⋅H2O}∞; (M = Co, 1; Cu, 2; Zn, 3), were inadvertently isolated when corresponding metal tetrafluoroborates were reacted with pyrimidine in glass vials. The crystal structures of complexes 1-3 revealed spontaneously resolved P (1) and M (2 and 3) helical coordination polymers in enantiomorphic space groups, despite the high molecular symmetry associated with the constituent building blocks.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of chiral network structures is one of the interesting topics of contemporary supramolecular chemistry. Chirality as a molecular property is well-understood, but transferring the concept of chirality to the crystalline lattice is very poorly understood by chemists. Besides pure enantiomers, achiral or even symmetric molecules can crystallize in any one of the chiral or enantiomorphic space groups that may only accommodate optically active solid-state structures, as long as their overall structure is chiral. Further, possession of chirality is an inherent property of helical structures. Therefore, any design strategy aimed at the deliberate synthesis of helices needs to address the problem of designing chiral network structures.
elements.clean_text: The design and synthesis of chiral network structures is one of the interesting topics of contemporary supramolecular chemistry. Chirality as a molecular property is well-understood, but transferring the concept of chirality to the crystalline lattice is very poorly understood by chemists. Besides pure enantiomers, achiral or even symmetric molecules can crystallize in any one of the chiral or enantiomorphic space groups that may only accommodate optically active solid-state structures, as long as their overall structure is chiral. Further, possession of chirality is an inherent property of helical structures. Therefore, any design strategy aimed at the deliberate synthesis of helices needs to address the problem of designing chiral network structures.

elements.content: In recent years, the design of metal-directed helicates from spontaneous self-assembly of conformationally flexible achiral ligands with complementary metal binding sites has produced fascinating single, double, triple, and circular helicate systems. The key design element of these strategies hinges on the conformational flexibility of the ligands that cause the twist required to form the helical structures. However, our recent studies on 1:1 pyrimidine:metal complexes and studies by other workers on complexes of angular bifunctional ligands suggest that this type of ligand has the ability to form many conformational isomers when coordinated with suitable metal salts. Our further attempts to understand the role of anions, water molecules, and angular bifunctional ligands in the context of crystal engineering uncovered both novel P and M enantiomorphic forms of helical coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: In recent years, the design of metal-directed helicates from spontaneous self-assembly of conformationally flexible achiral ligands with complementary metal binding sites has produced fascinating single, double, triple, and circular helicate systems. The key design element of these strategies hinges on the conformational flexibility of the ligands that cause the twist required to form the helical structures. However, our recent studies on 1:1 pyrimidine:metal complexes and studies by other workers on complexes of angular bifunctional ligands suggest that this type of ligand has the ability to form many conformational isomers when coordinated with suitable metal salts. Our further attempts to understand the role of anions, water molecules, and angular bifunctional ligands in the context of crystal engineering uncovered both novel P and M enantiomorphic forms of helical coordination polymers.

elements.content: When hydrated metal salts M(BF4)2·xH2O, (M = Co, Cu, Zn) were dissolved in acetonitrile and layered with methanolic solutions of pyrimidine in 1:1 molar ratios in glass vials, three isomorphous chiral coordination complexes containing SiF6 2-, {[M(pyrimidine)(OH2)4][SiF6]·H2O}∞, (M = Co, 1; Cu, 2; Zn, 3), were formed. HF generated in the reaction mixture, likely by hydrolysis of BF4 - anions, attacked the glass surface to form SiF6 2- and these larger anions preferentially crystallized over BF4 -, most likely due to more efficient crystal packing. The presence of SiF6 2- in 1−3 has been confirmed by 19F NMR spectroscopy and X-ray analysis.
elements.clean_text: When hydrated metal salts M(BF4)2⋅xH2O, (M = Co, Cu, Zn) were dissolved in acetonitrile and layered with methanolic solutions of pyrimidine in 1:1 molar ratios in glass vials, three isomorphous chiral coordination complexes containing SiF6 2-, {[M(pyrimidine)(OH2)4][SiF6]⋅H2O}∞, (M = Co, 1; Cu, 2; Zn, 3), were formed. HF generated in the reaction mixture, likely by hydrolysis of BF4 - anions, attacked the glass surface to form SiF6 2- and these larger anions preferentially crystallized over BF4 -, most likely due to more efficient crystal packing. The presence of SiF6 2- in 1-3 has been confirmed by 19F NMR spectroscopy and X-ray analysis.

elements.content: Interestingly, all three complexes crystallize in the enantiomeric, tetragonal space groups P43212 and P41212. The Co2+ helix (1) crystallizes in the right-handed space group, P43212, whereas the Cu2+ (2) and Zn2+ (3) helices crystallize in the left-handed space group P41212. The asymmetric units of all three complexes consist of the metal cation, one pyrimidine ligand, two unique, partially occupied, SiF6 2- anions, and five molecules of H2O. The metal cations in 1−3 are octahedrally coordinated with two bridging pyrimidines and four water molecules (Figure ). The two coordinated pyrimidine groups make an interplanar angle of 73.3−74.0°. As a result of this twist, 1−3 form helical one-dimensional coordination polymers with each period containing four pyrimidine units and having pitch lengths of 19.3−19.7 Å (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, all three complexes crystallize in the enantiomeric, tetragonal space groups P43212 and P41212. The Co2+ helix (1) crystallizes in the right-handed space group, P43212, whereas the Cu2+ (2) and Zn2+ (3) helices crystallize in the left-handed space group P41212. The asymmetric units of all three complexes consist of the metal cation, one pyrimidine ligand, two unique, partially occupied, SiF6 2- anions, and five molecules of H2O. The metal cations in 1-3 are octahedrally coordinated with two bridging pyrimidines and four water molecules (Figure ). The two  coordinated pyrimidine groups make an interplanar angle of 73.3-74.0°. As a result of this twist, 1-3 form helical one-dimensional coordination polymers with each period containing four pyrimidine units and having pitch lengths of 19.3-19.7 Å (Figure ).

elements.content: View of the one−dimensional P helical chain of1 propagating along the crystallographic c-axis. Hydrogen atoms, SiF6 2- anions, and noncoordinated H2O molecules were omitted.
elements.clean_text: 2  View of the one-dimensional P helical chain of1 propagating along the crystallographic c-axis. Hydrogen atoms, SiF6 2- anions, and noncoordinated H2O molecules were omitted.

elements.content: The uncoordinated water molecule and SiF6 2- anions form a complex and extensive three-dimensional hydrogen-bonded network with the coordinated water molecules through O−H···O and O−H···F hydrogen bonds (Figure ). One of the key elements in the hydrogen bonding that links the helices together is the uncoordinated water molecule, which is able to act as both a hydrogen bond donor and acceptor. As an acceptor, coordinated water molecules on two adjacent helical chains form hydrogen bonds to it, and as a donor, it forms further hydrogen bonds to two separate SiF6 2- anions.
elements.clean_text: The uncoordinated water molecule and SiF6 2- anions form a complex and extensive three-dimensional hydrogen-bonded network with the coordinated water molecules through O-H⋅⋅⋅O and O-H⋅⋅⋅F hydrogen bonds (Figure ). One of the key elements in the hydrogen bonding that links the helices together is the uncoordinated water molecule, which is able to act as both a hydrogen bond donor and acceptor. As an acceptor, coordinated water molecules on two adjacent helical chains form hydrogen bonds to it, and as a donor, it forms further hydrogen bonds to two separate SiF6 2- anions.

elements.content: View of two adjacent chains of3, showing the extensive network of hydrogen bonds between the helical chains, the SiF6 2- anions, and H2O molecules. Only one form of the disordered SiF6 2- anions is shown for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  View of two adjacent chains of3, showing the extensive network of hydrogen bonds between the helical chains, the SiF6 2- anions, and H2O molecules. Only one form of the disordered SiF6 2- anions is shown for clarity.

elements.content: Four related pyrimidine-containing coordination polymers of Co(II), Cu(II), and Zn(II) have previously been prepared and characterized. These consist of [M(pyrimidine)(OH2)2(NO3)2]∞, with M = Co, Cu, and Zn, and [Cu(pyrimidine)(hfac)]∞ (hfac = 1,1,1,5,5,5-hexafluoropentane-2,4-dionato). All four of these complexes are one-dimensional coordination polymers; however, unlike 1−3, none of them are helical, although the Cu-hfac complex shows some twisted sections. In the three NO3 - complexes, the NO3 - anions are coordinated to the metal center, blocking coordination of additional water molecules. In addition, the pyrimidine rings of these complexes are planar across the metal cation. These two factors lead to a reduction in the hydrogen-bonding possibilities for these complexes and prevent them from forming helices. Interestingly, the reaction of [Cu(MeCN)4]BF4 with pyrimidine has previously been seen to produce a three-dimensional coordination polymer, {[Cu(pyrimidine)2]BF4}∞, which shows no sign of hydrolysis of BF4 - nor leaching of SiF6 2- anions.
elements.clean_text: Four related pyrimidine-containing coordination polymers of Co(II), Cu(II), and Zn(II) have previously been prepared and characterized. These consist of [M(pyrimidine)(OH2)2(NO3)2]∞, with M = Co, Cu, and Zn, and [Cu(pyrimidine)(hfac)]∞ (hfac = 1,1,1,5,5,5-hexafluoropentane-2,4-dionato). All four of these complexes are one-dimensional coordination polymers; however, unlike 1-3, none of them are helical, although the Cu-hfac complex shows some twisted sections. In the three NO3 - complexes, the NO3 - anions are coordinated to the metal center, blocking coordination of additional water molecules. In addition, the pyrimidine rings of these complexes are planar across the metal cation. These two factors lead to a reduction in the hydrogen-bonding possibilities for these complexes and prevent them from forming helices. Interestingly, the reaction of [Cu(MeCN)4]BF4 with pyrimidine has previously been seen to produce a three-dimensional coordination polymer, {[Cu(pyrimidine)2]BF4}∞, which shows no sign of hydrolysis of BF4 - nor leaching of SiF6 2- anions.

elements.content: The fact that, despite the high molecular symmetry associated with the pyrimidine ligands and octahedral metal sites, 1−3 crystallized in optically active crystalline space groups is interesting. Isolation of the P helix 1 in right-handed and M helices 2−3 in left-handed space groups raises the interesting question of whether the chiral crystals obtained in the solution mixture underwent spontaneous enantiomer resolution on crystallization or were conglomerates (i.e., mechanical mixtures of enantiomerically pure crystals). To search for optical isomers of these complexes, we collected three full additional data sets on complex 2 grown from three different solvents, MeOH, MeCN, and MeOH/MeCN. The final structural results from all three data sets yielded the helical polymer in P41212 only. In spite of this, it is likely that the complexes were present as conglomerates, particularly as 1 was found as the right-handed form and the isomorphous 2 and 3 as the left-handed form.
elements.clean_text: The fact that, despite the high molecular symmetry associated with the pyrimidine ligands and octahedral metal sites, 1-3 crystallized in optically active crystalline space groups is interesting. Isolation of the P helix 1 in right-handed and M helices 2-3 in left-handed space groups raises the interesting question of whether the chiral crystals obtained in the solution mixture underwent spontaneous enantiomer resolution on crystallization or were conglomerates (i.e., mechanical mixtures of enantiomerically pure crystals). To search for optical isomers of these complexes, we collected three full additional data sets on complex 2 grown from three different solvents, MeOH, MeCN, and MeOH/MeCN. The final structural results from all three data sets yielded the helical polymer in P41212 only. In spite of this, it is likely that the complexes were present as conglomerates, particularly as 1 was found as the right-handed form and the isomorphous 2 and 3 as the left-handed form.

elements.content: Formation of the chiral helical polymers in 1−3 as opposed to the previously observed planar zigzag polymers may have been the result of variations in steric interactions between the pyrimidine units and co-ligands on the metal centers and also hydrogen-bonding interactions between the coligands. It is likely that the energy difference between various possible conformational isomers of 1D polymers in 1−3, and related complexes, is small enough that subtle changes in intra- and intermolecular interactions can contribute to supramolecular isomerism and the differing crystalline networks. The coordination of four water molecules to the metal centers in 1−3, in contrast to the coordination of two anions and two water molecules in previous complexes, allowed the formation of a more extensive hydrogen-bonded network, and thus the relatively weaker interchain face-to-face π-stacking interactions were not observed.
elements.clean_text: Formation of the chiral helical polymers in 1-3 as opposed to the previously observed planar zigzag polymers may have been the result of variations in steric interactions between the pyrimidine units and co-ligands on the metal centers and also hydrogen-bonding interactions between the coligands. It is likely that the energy difference between various possible conformational isomers of 1D polymers in 1-3, and related complexes, is small enough that subtle changes in intra- and intermolecular interactions can contribute to supramolecular isomerism and the differing crystalline networks. The coordination of four water molecules to the metal centers in 1-3, in contrast to the coordination of two anions and two water molecules in previous complexes, allowed the formation of a more extensive hydrogen-bonded network, and thus the relatively weaker interchain face-to-face π-stacking interactions were not observed.

elements.content: The packing of the structures was also influenced by the four coordinated water molecules. To keep the hydrophobic parts of the complexes separated from the hydrophilic, the complexes packed to show two discrete domains (Figure ), when viewed down the crystallographic c-axis. The hydrophilic domains comprise the [M(H2O)4]2+ core and the noncoordinated H2O molecules, whereas the hydrophobic domains comprise the pyrimidine ligands. The two domains can be seen to be linked together by the SiF6 2- anions (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: The packing of the structures was also influenced by the four coordinated water molecules. To keep the hydrophobic parts of the complexes separated from the hydrophilic, the complexes packed to show two discrete domains (Figure ), when viewed down the crystallographic c-axis. The hydrophilic domains comprise the [M(H2O)4]2+ core and the noncoordinated H2O molecules, whereas the hydrophobic domains comprise the pyrimidine ligands. The two domains can be seen to be linked together by the SiF6 2- anions (Figure ).

elements.content: View of the packing of3 down the crystallographic c-axis, where hydrophobic ligand domains (one highlighted blue) and hydrophilic water domains (one highlighted green) can be seen, separated by SiF6 2- anions. A single helical chain has been highlighted in dark red. (Hydrogen atoms and disordered forms of the SiF6 2- anions were omitted for clarity.)

A single helical chain has been highlighted in dark red. (Hydrogen atoms and disordered forms of the SiF6 2- anions were omitted for clarity.)

elements.content: In summary, our present studies have found interesting P and M enantiomorphic helical complexes from simple nonchiral, symmetric building blocks, suggesting that with a suitable design strategy and experimental conditions, we can deliberately design and synthesize chiral complexes. Finally, the helical coordination polymers reported here provide a simple alternate strategy for the construction of metal-directed helices using simple, rigid bifunctional ligands in contrast to enantiomerically pure chiral ligands.
elements.clean_text: In summary, our present studies have found interesting P and M enantiomorphic helical complexes from simple nonchiral, symmetric building blocks, suggesting that with a suitable design strategy and experimental conditions, we can deliberately design and synthesize chiral complexes. Finally, the helical coordination polymers reported here provide a simple alternate strategy for the construction of metal-directed helices using simple, rigid bifunctional ligands in contrast to enantiomerically pure chiral ligands.

elements.content: Experimental details for the syntheses of 1−3, topological analysis of the network formed by 1−3 (PDF). X-ray crystallographic information files (CIF) for all three structures. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title:
Enantiomorphic Helical Coordination Polymers of
{[M(pyrimidine)(OH2)4][SiF6]·H2O}∞ (M = Co2+, Cu2+, Zn2+)
